questions.text: What is the most common anatomical position of the appendix?
questions.solution:
Retrocaecal is the most common position of the appendix.

Positions of appendix:

  • Retrocaecal: 74%
  • Pelvic: 21%
  • Sub-cecal: 1.5%
  • Pre-ileal: 1%
  • Post-ileal: 0.5%

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the various anatomical positions of the appendix?

choices.text: Tenderness may be elicited on the immediate right of the umbilicus in post-ileal appendicitis
The most common location of the base of the appendix is retro-caecal
An inflamed pelvic appendix may cause an increase in frequency of micturition
Post-ileal appendicitis may have diarrhoea as a presenting complaint

questions.solution:
The base of the appendix is found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum. Its position is constant. Conversely, the tip of the appendix can be found in many positions ( retrocaecal being the most common)

The taeniae coli fuse to form the longitudinal muscle coat of the appendix. During surgery, gentle traction at the taenia coli, leads the surgeon to the base of the appendix.

questions.text: During an appendectomy, the mesoappendix is divided and ligated. Which of the following is false about the major vessel ligated in this step?

choices.text: It is a branch of upper division of the ileocolic artery
Thrombosis is most common at the tip

questions.solution:
During appendectomy, the appendicular artery is the major vessel that is ligated when the mesoappendix is divided. It is a branch of the lower division of the ileocolic artery.

The appendicular artery transverses behind the terminal ileum and enters the mesoappendix away from the base of the appendix. It lies along the free border of the mesoappendix. The terminal part or the tip of the artery lies on the wall of the appendix and may become thrombosed in appendicitis, resulting in distal gangrene or necrosis.

It supplies only the appendix and is an end-artery.

An accessory appendicular artery called the artery of Seshachalam may be present. It anastomoses at the base of the appendix with a branch of the posterior cecal artery.

questions.text: While assisting a laparoscopic appendectomy, you observe the resident use the Fold of Treves as a guide while coagulating vessels in the mesoappendix. Which of the following best describes the anatomical landmark?

choices.text: Mucous membrane projecting into the ileal lumen
The ilio-cecal fold of the peritoneum
The fold of the mucous membrane around appendiceal orifice
The fold of the peritoneum over ascending colon

questions.solution:
Fold of Treves is an antimesenteric ileocecal fold of peritoneum. 

A clinical aid useful for detecting the location of the appendix through small abdominal incisions is the identification of the fold of Treves. It marks the junction of the ileum and cecum. As it does not contain any vessel, it is referred to as the bloodless fold of Treves. It is also used as a guide to determine the extent of coagulation during an appendectomy. This prevents thermal injury to adjacent structures.

Jackson Membrane: Adhesion from the right abdominal wall to the anterior tenia of the ascending colon.

Gerlach valves: A mucosal fold covering the appendiceal orifice.

questions.text: The CECT findings of a patient who presented with a positive McBurney's sign show a dilated appendix, appendicular wall thickening, and fat stranding. What is the initiating event that leads to his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of appendicitis. The initiating event in the development of appendicitis is luminal obstruction.

Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acute appendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus. It is where the appendix is commonly located.

Due to the relatively small diameter of the appendicular lumen, it is easily obstructed. Usually, due to fecoliths. This leads to the buildup of mucus secretions and air due to bacteria. With progressive dilation, venous drainage may get hampered, leading to full-thickness ischemia and perforation.

Obstructed lumen of appendix → Retained secretions with distension of lumen → Secretions get infected → Venous occlussion due to increased pressure → Bacterial translocation → Gangrene & perforation → Appendicular abscess

questions.text: What is the earliest symptom in a patient with acute appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Symptoms of acute appendicitis begin as periumbilical pain followed by anorexia and nausea.

Acute appendicitis begins with poorly localized colicky abdominal pain, first noticed in the periumbilical region. This is due to midgut visceral discomfort (T8 to T10 dermatomes) in response to appendiceal inflammation and obstruction.

Over the next 12-24 hours, it localises to the right lower quadrant due to local peritoneal inflammation.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty with right lower abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. On examination, there is increased pain in the right lower quadrant when palpating the left lower quadrant. What is this sign is called?
questions.solution:
The given triad of clinical features, namely fever, nausea and right lower abdominal pain is Murphy's triad. It is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa can cause pain in the right iliac fossa. This sign is called Rovsing’s sign.

This pain is due to the backflow of gases from the colon into the inflamed right intestine when the left lower abdomen is palpated.

questions.text: You are examining a patient suspected to have appendicitis. During the given manoeuvre, you notice that the  patient has sharp right-sided abdominal pain. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: This sign elicited is known as Psoas Sign
It is commonly associated with pelvic appendicitis
Flexion of the hip against resistance may be done instead
Pain is due to contact of inflamed appendix with the psoas muscle

questions.solution:
The manoeuvre in the given image shows hyperextension of the hip joint. It can induce abdominal pain when there is irritation of the psoas muscle by the inflamed appendix. This is known as the psoas sign and is commonly seen in retrocecal appendicitis.

Flexion of the hip against resistance also elicits the psoas sign.

Pain elicited on hip flexion and internal rotation is called the obturator sign. It is commonly seen in pelvic appendicitis.

questions.text: A young boy was brought to the casualty with a history of fever and abdominal pain. On examination, he was febrile and his pulse rate was 104 beats/min. The CT scan image is shown below. Which of the following  signs is not seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The patient's history and radiological findings are indicative of acute appendicitis. Ballance sign is not seen in acute appendicitis.

Findings on CT that are suggestive of acute appendicitis include:

  • Appendiceal dilatation (>6 mm in diameter) 
  • Appendiceal wall thickening (>3 mm) and enhancement

Ballance sign is seen due to a ruptured spleen. The ballance sign is positive if there is a fixed dullness to percussion in the left flank and shifting dullness to percussion in the right flank. The fixed dullness is due to the presence of coagulated blood near the lacerated spleen while the shifting dullness is due to the presence of blood in the peritoneal cavity.

Option A: Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acute appendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus.

Option B: Rovsing sign is seen in appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa may cause pain in the right iliac fossa.

Option C: Psoas sign is seen in appendicitis. Occasionally, an inﬂamed appendix lies on the psoas muscle, and the patient will lie with the right hip ﬂexed, for pain relief.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the casualty with a history of abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 4 hours. On examination, the patient is febrile. Rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa is seen. Which among the following is the preferred imaging modality in this patient?

choices.text: Erect X Ray of the abdomen

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute appendicitis. In the pediatric population, ultrasound of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality to identify the presence of an inflamed appendix. It avoids the risk of radiation exposure. 

In adults, the best imaging modality is a CT scan.

questions.text:
For which of the following criteria on the Alvarado system, will you assign 2 points to a patient with features of appendicitis?

1. Leukocytosis ≥ 10⨯109 cells/L

2. Migratory right iliac fossa pain

3. Tenderness in the right iliac fossa

4. Rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa

5. Fever
questions.solution:
The Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. In the Alvorado scoring system, leukocytosis ≥ 10 × 109 cells/L  and tenderness right iliac fossa have two points. 

Related Pearl: Alvarado Scoring System

A score of 4-5 or below rules out the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children, and in adults, a score of 8-9 or higher rules in the diagnosis.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and right lower quadrant pain for the past week. On examination, tenderness and guarding in the right iliac fossa are present. An ill-defined abdominal mass is also palpated. CBC reveals leucocytosis. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In appendicular mass, the inflammatory process is already localized and any surgical intervention may be difficult and dangerous. Hence, if the general condition is satisfactory, the conservative Ochsner–Sherren regimen is used.

Related Pearl: Oshner Sherren Regimen

Principle :

  • The inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous.
  • It may be impossible to find the appendix and, occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.
  • Antibiotic therapy should be given after performing CECT abdomen
  • Abscess if present can be drained radiologically.

Outcome :

  • Improvement in 24–48 h
  • 90% cases resolve
  • Failure should raise suspicion of Crohn’s disease and carcinoma. 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of Appendicular mass:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increasing size of the mass

questions.text: Identify the incision made on a patient while performing an appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
Lanz incision is a transverse skin crease incision for appendicitis 2 cm below the  umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid inguinal line

Option A: Gridiron incision is an oblique muscle-splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. It is also called McBurney incision.

Option C: Rutherford–Morrison incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

Option D: Rockey–Davis incision is a transverse right lower quadrant incision.

questions.text:
A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut?
  1. External oblique 
  2. Internal oblique 
  3. Transversus abdominis
  4. Rectus abdominis
questions.solution:
The structures cut when the initial incision gridiron incision (McBurney's incision) is converted to the Rutherford Morrison incision are the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverse abdominis muscles.

When the preoperative diagnosis is reasonably certain, the widely used incision for appendectomy is known as the gridiron incision. It is made perpendicular to a line connecting the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus, with its center at McBurney's point. When better access is needed, the gridiron incision can be converted to a Rutherford Morison incision by extending the incision obliquely upwards and laterally. 

Rutherford Morison's incision is suitable for a para- or retrocecal appendix that is fixed. It is an oblique muscle-cutting incision starting from McBurney's point and extending upward and laterally as needed. All layers (skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and the peritoneum) are divided along the incision line.

In recent years, the transverse skin crease (Lanz) incision has gained popularity due to improved exposure and ease of extension when necessary. This incision is placed approximately 2 cm below the umbilicus along the midclavicular-midinguinal line, with its length adjusted according to the patient's size and obesity. If required, the incision can be extended medially by retracting or dividing the rectus abdominis muscle (statement 4).

When there is uncertainty in the diagnosis, especially in the presence of intestinal obstruction, a lower midline abdominal incision is preferred over a right lower paramedian incision.

questions.text: As a surgical resident performing an appendectomy, what is the maximum stump size that you can leave behind in order to prevent stump appendicitis?
questions.solution:
The residual appendiceal stump should be no longer than 5 mm, so as to minimize the possibility of stump appendicitis in the future.

Stump appendicitis is a complication that occurs after an appendectomy. It is caused by the inflammation of the residual appendiceal tissue after the appendix is removed. The clinical presentation of stump appendicitis is similar to acute appendicitis.

Factors predisposing for stump appendicitis:

  • Inadequate identification of the appendicular base due to severe local inflammation
  • Leaving a long stump due to fear of cecal injury or difficult dissection
  • Local ulcerations due to fecoliths.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy is taken up for open appendicectomy. Which of the combinations of the following instruments is best suited for his procedure?
questions.solution:
Babcock's forceps, 22 size blade, and Langenbeck retractor are used in open appendicectomy.

The image below shows Babcock’s forceps, where:

  • Distal part of distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • Tip is non traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in proximal part.

Uses:

  • Hold any part of Bowel, Fallopian tube, Appendix, Ureter, Cord, etc.

The below image is that of a Langenbeck Retractor:

  • Useful for holding open wounds, as in an open appendicectomy.
  • Often used in pairs (one in each of the assistant’s hands).
  • The width of the lip of the retractors varies.

The 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy

The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions

15-blade for minor surgical procedures.

Deaver’s Retractor is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver.

Lane’s tissue holding forceps

  • It has got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestra in each blade
  • Apposing tooth in the tip
  • Lock in proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes.

Tracheal dilator is used to keep tracheostomy open.

questions.text: What is the most common post-operative complication that may arise in patients who undergo an appendectomy ?
questions.solution:
Wound infection is the most common postoperative complication of appendectomy.

Related Pearl: Complications of Appendicectomy

  • Wound infection: 5–10%
  • Intra-abdominal abscess: 8%
  • Post operative ileus
  • Respiratory complications
  • Venous thrombo-embolism
  • Portal pyemia- septicemia in portal venous system, can lead to hepatic abscess.
  • Adhesive intestinal obstruction: 1–3% (MC late post op complication)
  • Fecal fistula
  • Port site hernias.
  • Appendico-cutaneous fistula or appendico-vesical fistula: rare
  • Mortality after appendicectomy is less than 1%

questions.text: What is the most common neoplasm of the appendix ?
questions.solution:
The most common neoplasm primarily identified in the appendix are carcinoid tumors. 

They account for approximately 66% of all tumors of the appendix. They are detected in 0.3 to 0.9% of appendectomy specimens.

Adenocarcinoma of the appendix is very rare, accounting for 0.5% of all gastrointestinal cancers. The adenocarcinoma malignancies are three subtypes:

  • Mucinous
  • Colonic type 
  • Adenocarcinoid

Mucinous is the most common subtype whereas Adenocarcinoid is the rarest.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about carcinoid tumours of appendix?

choices.text: Size appears to be the best predictor of malignant behavior and metastatic potential
Arise from Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Lieberkühn
Most common location is the base of the appendix

questions.solution:
The most common location of the carcinoid tumour of the appendix is the tip of the appendix i.e., the distal third of the appendix.

A carcinoid tumour, also known as argentaffinoma, arises in argentaffin tissue (Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Lieberkühn). It often presents with symptoms of subacute or recurrent appendicitis.

On gross examination, it is a moderately hard, yellow tumour between the intact mucosa and the peritoneum. Microscopically, tumour cells are small, arranged in small nests within the muscle, and have a characteristic pattern using immunohistochemical stain for chromogranin B. 

Carcinoid tumours are the most common appendiceal tumours but they rarely metastasize.

Treatment includes appendicectomy. Indications for right hemicolectomy along with appendectomy are :

  • Involvement of the cecal wall
  • Tumour is 2 cm or more in size
  • Lymph nodes are involved.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient is admitted to the hospital for complaints of pain and tenderness in the right iliac fossa. She underwent an appendicectomy. A 2.5 cm tumor was encountered at the base of the appendix which was found to be carcinoid on histopathological examination. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Send the urine for 5- hydroxy indole acetic acid levels

questions.solution:
The carcinoid tumors of the appendix which are more than 2 cm in size are treated with right hemicolectomy.

Management of carcinoid tumors:

  • <1 cm – Appendicectomy
  • 1-2 cms - Appendicectomy or right hemicolectomy depending on the individual tumor characteristics.
  • >2 cm – Right hemicolectomy

Irrespective of size, it is recommended to perform a right hemicolectomy in:

  • Carcinoids at the appendiceal base (<2 cm from the base)
  • Lymphatic invasion or lymph node involvement
  • Spread to the mesoappendix
  • Tumor-positive resection margins
  • Cellular pleomorphism with a high mitotic index.

questions.text: Following an appendectomy, the specimen was sent for HPE. A well-circumscribed, yellowish tumor measuring 0.5 cm in diameter at the tip of the appendix was seen. The stained sections revealed a typical carcinoid tumor of the appendix. The specimen had a tumor-free margin on all sides. The base of the appendix, the mesoappendix, and nodes were not involved. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The size of the carcinoid tumour is 0.5 cm (<1 cm), the margins of the resected specimen are tumour free, and there is no involvement of appendix base, mesoappendix, or lymph nodes. The best management approach here is observation. 

Carcinoid tumour may be detected in ~0.5% of appendectomy specimens. Appendectomy is adequate in the treatment of cases with a diameter of <1 cm and in those with a diameter of 1-2 cm without lymphovascular invasion.

If a tumour is found after appendicectomy: 

  • If it is an adenocarcinoma, perform right hemicolectomy.
  • If it is a carcinoid tumour, treatment differs according to the tumour size:
    • <1 cm – Observation
    • 1–2 cm – Right hemicolectomy if a lymphovascular invasion is seen
    • >2 cm – Right hemicolectomy

Right hemicolectomy treatment is indicated even in tumours < 2 cm in case of:

  • Tumours localized at the base of the appendix
  • Invasion of lymphatic ducts, serosa and mesoappendix
  • Presence of regional lymph node metastasis
  • Positive surgical margins 
  • Mucin production (mucinous carcinoid tumours)
  • High mitotic fast cellular pleomorphism

questions.text: A 6-year-old presented with right lower quadrant pain and fever for 1 day. An appendicitis was suspected and the patient was prepared for surgery. During the surgery, a normal appendix was found but mesenteric lymph nodes were enlarged. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Yersinia enterocolitica causes inflammation of the terminal ileum, appendix, and cecum, alongwith mesenteric lymphadenopathy. It is the most common differential diagnosis of acute appendicitis. 

Acute mesenteric lymphadenitis manifests as acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain associated with mesenteric lymph node enlargement and a normal appendix. Diagnosis is made after exploration of the abdomen of a patient suspected of having acute appendicitis, which reveals a normal appendix and enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes. It usually occurs in children and young adults.

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady diagnosed with mucinous cystadenoma appendix is unwilling for surgery. A few weeks later, she complains of vague abdominal pain and progressive abdominal distension. Ultrasound reveals the presence of ascites. CT reveals a thickened peritoneum, multiple loculated fluid collections, and scalloping of the liver and spleen margin. Which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?

choices.text: The patient is most likely suffering from disseminated peritoneal carcinomatosis
The histology of the appendiceal tumor is an important predictor of survival
Cytoreductive surgery with IPHC maybe required for management
This condition can also occur in patients with ovarian neoplasms

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with mucinous cystadenoma appendix and imaging findings are suggestive of pseudomyxoma peritonei. 

Pseudomyxoma peritonei refers to a condition of mucinous ascites arising due to the rupture of a mucinous tumor of appendix or ovary. It most commonly occurs in patients between 40-50 years of age. They are often asymptomatic or present with non-specific complaints like abdominal pain and distension.

Physical examination may reveal ascites with non shifting dullness and rarely, a palpable abdominal mass. CT scan may reveal accumulation of mucinous material and scalloped indentation of the visceral surfaces of the liver and spleen. The peritoneal surfaces may be thickened due to the solid components of the tumor. The histology of the primary appendiceal tumor is an important predictor of survival.
Management consists of extensive resection of the tumor (cytoreduction) and intraperitoneal heated chemotherapy (IPHC). Surgical management may include omentectomy, resection of the peritoneum and involved organs, appendectomy or a right hemicolectomy.
